reviewText: Any fan of Mystery Science Theater would absolutely love this DVD.  It is hysterically funny and definitely worth buying and watching.

reviewText: Mike, Kevin and Bill are comic genius, and watching this series of shorts is pure fun! One of the pieces was obviously meant to be an educational film--all about America and American families--OMG--loved it loved it!! That was a true trip down memory lane only made more funny from my favorite Rifftrax guys-FIVE stars!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Bring the guys in from Mystery Science Theater 3000 and now Rifftrax in, have 9 educational and droning shorts for them to mock and you have a great and funny time for fans of bad films and great riffing.-What It Means To Be An American: How do you view your city, state or country? Well if you watch this well meaning but incredibly boring short, you may want avoid the outside and just stay in your home. There's random shots of various U.S. landmarks, cities and other things all the while a narrator talks about how good America and its people are. The crew does well but the running time is a bit long.-Going Steady: If you're a girl seeing a guy who ends up asking your best friend to a dance before he asks you, what do you do? Why decide to go steady with him of course. Ah the early 50's dating scene, where every teenager appeared to be at least 28 if not older but still in high school. Its funny and the guys just tear it apart.-Understanding Your Ideals: A boy wants to take a girl to a dance but his plan is thwarted when his parents go to grandmas to take care of her and can't let him have the car. He of course is bummed and cancels the plans claiming sickness, but is found out later and must come to grips with and realize what it really means to be popular with the right people. Funny jokes ensue as they always do well with these 50's shorts.-A Circus Wakes Up: We see a behind the scenes view of how people and animals wake up and get ready to perform. The guys just rip it apart and have a blast. Easily a highlight of the disc.-Highway Mania: Traffic safety in the 50's and a crazy, melting maniac who randomly pops up seemingly out of nowhere drives around showing how not to drive. This is the best short on the disc as its laugh out loud funny on so many moments.-Teenagers on Trial: Some teens commit a crime and the debate occurs whether they should go easy on them or give them a long term jail sentence. Its funny but at times a bit blah. Still some good riffs from the guys.-Women In Blue: We see women in the military as they are shown in a light that well was a lot like most women were shown in the '40's and 50's, not very strong that is. But that doesn't stop the crew from doing what they do best, riff and riff away to prevent boredom and often good results follow.-Wing, Claw and Fang!: We see various trained animals in everyday life, namely a penguin going to a fish market and a lion and his trainer wrestling..... at least I hope thats what it is. This is another funny one as animal based shorts work well with the crew.-Constance Bennett's Daily Beauty Rituals: Whomever she is, this is what she does to get ready in the morning or maybe afternoon, hard to tell and even harder to care. Its not bad but kinda blah, not that the guys don't try hard but its not that great.Its a disc worth having if your a fan of MST3K and Rifftrax, most of them are funny and even the somewhat blah ones have there moments.
summary: Driving spider monkeys, what else do you need?
Title: N/A

reviewText: The hilarious Rifftrax crew do it again with some really odd shorts. One of the funniest things about these were their function: were they meant for educational purposes? informing the unsuspecting public? or a way to distract the students while the teachers snuck away for a wee nip or nicotine fix? It's a real blast to see the 50s family unit in 'What it Means to Be an American', the correct proper dating guidelines in 'Going Steady' and two double creature features in 'A Circus Wakes Up' and 'Wing Claw & Fang'. You can never go wrong with social deviance as demonstrated in 'Teenagers on Trial' or the female power brigade of 'Women in Blue'. However, the topper for me is the strange twilight zonish, drivers ed short of the risk of becoming another accident fatality in 'Highway Mania'. This is just an example of what Rifftrax does best.

reviewText: The MST3K gang ,well half of them.Mike,Bill and Kevin have to be three of the best writer/comedians that take really boring movies and turn them in to hilarious gold laugh out loud riffs.speaking of riffs their new project's titled under Rifftrax are just an extentsion of MST3K.I own most of their material.Can't get enough of these guy's.

reviewText: Mike Nelson, Kevin Murphy, & Bill Corbett riff their way over nine historic and hysteric shorts in the appropriately named collection "Rifftrax Plays with Their Shorts". While the subjects are wide ranging, a "patriotic" theme rears it's head in three of the shorts.We begin with a collection of stock footage of American cities and landmarks tied together with confusion narration in the really lame and confusing "What it Means to Be an American". A mousey teen must listen to her creepy Mom in "Going Steady?", while her so-called boyfriend is hitting up on other mousey teens."Understanding Your Ideals" can get confused with "Highway Mania" as they both deal with cars...in a way. "A Circus Wakes Up" is exactly that, unfortunately. A big highlight is "Teenagers on Trial" as pre-teen angst challenges Al Capone as America's biggest criminal threat. Although some of the footage is priceless as a teen girl downs a highball and has an expected reaction...mind if we ask a few questions?A condecending narrator overwelms America's female contribution to the war effort in "Women in Blue". Farm animals are humiliated in "Wing, Claw, & Fang" and we end with the Zsa Zsa Gabor of the 1930's Constance Bennett, who doles out make-up tips in "Constance Bennett's Daily Beauty Rituals".Like "Shorts-A-Poppin", the Rifftrax crew is at the top of their game with some great riffing in all the shorts. The sole extra is an "alternate riff" of the first five minutes of "What it Means to Be an American". Funny stuff for sure and well worth it for your collection.
summary: What it means to be Constance Bennett...who's Constance Bennett?

reviewText: This set is another winner.  These shorts are so bad that they are really good - but only because of the riffing.  I cannot even begin to describe how "What it Means to be an American" will make you first stand at attention and then fall down laughing - and that is BEFORE the riffing even starts.  And it goes on from there.  Thanks Mike, Kevin and Bill for doing all the hard work.

reviewText: I hate to, but I must. It pains me to give any work of Mike Nelson, Kevin Murphy, and Bill Corbett anything other than five stars, but on this occasion I just have to. I have unequivocally loved all the other RiffTrax shorts compilations, but "RiffTrax Plays With Their Shorts" mixes modestly funny riffs with an  absolutely terrible selection of short subjects, many of which are essentially interchangeable black and white teen angst showcases ("Going Steady," "Understanding Your Ideals," and "Teenagers on Trial.") Those three would be enough on their own to try the patience of even the most diehard Z-grade short subject aficionado, but if the other selections had been strong (like, say, "Drugs are Like That," or "Kitty Cleans Up") the collection would have still been an undisputed winner.Unfortunately they chose the 20 minute long epic "What it Means to be an American" as the centerpiece of the collection. Not only is it mind-numbingly long (it seems even longer, hence Mike's complaint about napping until they got to dealing with zither repairmen,) but it just isn't funny. For the first time in my personal RiffTrax (or MST3K) viewing history I considered not watching the entire thing; I ended up watching it in three segments. The film is a jumbled 1950's patriotic film with good intentions. It looks dated today, but is really a simple, meandering film of different American cities, institutions, and activities. It is exceedingly plodding, and is far, far too long to be entertaining for the vast majority of people including me, a devoted lover of the films of Coleman Francis. So how do Mike and the gang rub a bit more salt into this particular wound? They feature a bonus alternate take of five minutes of "What it Means to be an American" as the extra on the DVD. Talk about hitting below the belt. Ouch.There are a couple of bright points on the disc, notably the entertaining "Highway Mania," and the bizarre animal-centric shorts "A Circus Wakes Up," and (my personal favorite of the set,) "Wing, Claw, and Fang." These three are charmingly peculiar in their scope, and the riffs are great.I think the RiffTrax guys are brilliant, and given the amount of material they have produced over the years it's amazing that there aren't more clunkers out there. I don't regret buying this DVD, but it's definitely a letdown compared to their normal fare. As for the other RiffTrax shorts DVD sets, I recommend that you rush out and get them at once; if like me you're going to collect them all, I recommend you save this one until last.
summary: "Hey, I'm Gonna' Take A Nap; Tell Me When You Get To 'Zither Repairman.'"
Title: N/A
